question: A multi-way search tree of order N is a tree where each node can contain at most:
answers: N ordered values
N-1 ordered values
N children
N-1 ordered values and N children

question: In a multi-way search tree, what property is satisfied for a given node?
answers: The number of children is always equal to the number of values
The number of values is always equal to the degree
The number of values is always equal to the degree - 1
The number of children is always equal to the degree + 1

question: When searching for a value in a multi-way tree, what happens if the value does not exist in the current node?
answers: Access the first non-null child
Access the last non-null child
Access the child at the position where the value should be to maintain order
The search ends with a failure

question: In an inorder traversal of a multi-way tree, what is the order of visiting the nodes?
answers: Root, left child, right child
Left child, root, right child
Left child, right child, root
Right child, root, left child

question: How do you find the inorder successor of a value in a given node?
answers: It is the smallest non-null child of the node
It is the first larger value in the same node, otherwise the minimum of the right subtree
It is the last smaller value in the same node
It is the first ancestor from which we descend by a child other than the last one

question: When inserting a new value into a multi-way tree, what happens if the last visited node is full?
answers: Replace the first value of the node with the new one
Create a new node containing the new value
The insertion fails
Move the first value of the node into a new child node

question: A B-tree of order N is a balanced multi-way search tree satisfying the following properties:
answers: All nodes (except the root) have a minimum filling rate of 50%
The root can contain at least 1 value and 2 children
All leaves are at the same level
In an internal node, all children are different from -1. In a leaf node, all children are -1.

question: To insert a value x:
answers: Search for x. If x already exists, stop. Otherwise, let P be the visited leaf node.
If P is not full, insert x into P by shifting.
If P is full, split P into two nodes P and Q, inserting the median value into P's parent.
Recursively move up until a non-full node is found or a new root is created.

question: The split is done by:
answers: Forming the ordered sequence of P's values plus x
Splitting this sequence into 2, with the median value v going into the parent
The first half forming P, the second Q
Inserting (v, Q) into P's parent
